    • Using discovery and replication summary statistics for adjusting association estimates
    • Standard errors of adjusted estimates and confidence intervals
    • Obtaining adjusted `beta` estimates

MSE minimization method for use with discovery and replication GWASs

MSE_minimizer.Rd

Approach to combine association estimates from discovery and replication data sets

MSE_minimizer(summary_disc, summary_rep, alpha, spline = FALSE)

Arguments

summary_disc

A data frame containing summary statistics from the discovery GWAS. It must have three columns with column names rsid, beta and se, respectively, and all columns must contain numerical values.
summary_rep

A data frame containing summary statistics from the replication GWAS. It must have three columns with column names rsid, beta and se, respectively, and all columns must contain numerical values.
alpha

A numerical value which specifies the desired genome-wide significance threshold for the discovery GWAS.
spline

Logical parameter, default is spline=FALSE, spline=TRUE uses a cubic smoothing spline to predict value of B=summary_disc$beta - summary_rep$beta, spline=FALSE just uses this raw value for B

Value

Data frame with only SNPs deemed significance in discovery GWAS, contains their beta and se values from both discovery and replication GWAS as well as the combined estimate, beta_joint

References

Ferguson, J., Alvarez-Iglesias, A., Newell, J., Hinde, J., & O'Donnell, M. (2017). Joint incorporation of randomised and observational evidence in estimating treatment effects. Statistical Methods in Medical Research, 28(1), 235\(-\)247. https://doi.org/10.1177/0962280217720854
